topic.title: COPIPIF Overview

body.p: The Combined OTN and Packet Interface (COPI) Packet Interface (PIF) is configurable to operate in either 3x200G Interlaken mode or single 500G/600G Interlaken mode. In 3x200G Interlaken mode there are three Interlaken interfaces each with up to 12 lanes and capacity for 200G of channelized client packet bandwidth. In 3x200G, the total capacity between the DCPB and COPI is 200G. In single 500G Interlaken mode there is one Interlaken interface with up to 24 lanes and capacity for 500G of channelized client packet bandwidth. COPIPIF connects to the Central Packet Buffer (DCPB). It supports data transfers over up to 190120 channels. The DCPB provides combined packet and OTN traffic, and each Interlaken interface can carry packet traffic as a packet interface (PIF), or carry artificial ODUk packets as a constant bit rate interface (CBRI). Additionally, the single 500G Interlaken interface can carry a mix of PIF and CBRI traffic as a hybrid interface. In single 600G Interlaken mode only a single channel of PIF traffic is supported.

The Interlaken protocol is implemented in the ILKN500 block. The Interlaken transmit (fabric ingress) interfaces operate in segment interleave mode in which the DCPB and internal data busses switch between channels on burst boundaries and not necessarily on packet boundaries. The Interlaken receive (fabric egress) interfaces support data that is generated by an external device in packet or segment interleave mode. On the transmit side, bursts received from the DCPB are sent to the Interlaken blocks. The upstream DCPB performs Interlaken enhanced scheduling which ensures no bursts are shorter than the Interlaken BurstShort. The Interlaken blocks apply the Interlaken protocol and stripe the data across a software configured number of SERDES lanes. The Interlaken blocks provide an interface that allow them to be connected to SERDES blocks. On the receive side, the bursts received from SERDES are decoded and checked for protocol compliance. The data from each Interlaken interface is dropped or aggregated based on the channel ID, and sent to the DCPB port. Depending on the mode the channel ID may be specified in a lookup table which associates the channel ID with the Interlaken Burst Control Word header or the channel ID may be mapped from an inband packet header field.

The 3x200G Interlaken mode supports three Interlaken interfaces, each with up to 12 lanes that interface to 25.78125 Gbps rate NRZ SERDES. In the Interlaken transmit direction each DCPB channel can be independently broadcast to up to three Interlaken interfaces. In the Interlaken receive direction each DCPB channel can be independently configured to receive data from one of the three Interlaken interfaces.

The single 500G/600G Interlaken mode supports one Interlaken interface with up to 24 lanes that interface to 25.78125 Gbps or 28.125 Gbps rate NRZ SERDES, or up to 12 lanes that interface to 53.125 Gbps or 56.25 Gbps rate PAM-4 SERDES with FEC. In the Interlaken transmit direction each DCPB channel is mapped to one channel on the Interlaken interface. In the Interlaken receive direction each Interlaken channel is mapped to unique channels toward the DCPB. Note for 600G Interlaken mode, only a single channel of PIF traffic is supported.

The DCPB port pushes packets to the COPI500 in bursts up to the BurstMax size. The BurstMax sizes supported are 512/256/128 bytes per transfer. The BurstMax sizes are identically configured in the COPI500 and DCPB by software.

The COPIPIF integrates the ITS_PKT500 which can generate and monitor up to 120 channels of test packet traffic. The traffic can be generated either toward the DCPB or toward the Interlaken transmit path. The COPI500PIF includes merge logic that allow the generated traffic to merge in with the datapaths toward the DCPB and toward the Interlaken transmit path on burst boundaries, with priority given to the non-test traffic. The COPI500PIF includes channel switch logic that allow Interlaken receive data or DCPB data to be steered toward the test packet monitor or the normal datapaths, with selection on a per channel basis.

The COPI500 receive path provides ODUk packet latency monitors on the receive bus facing the DCPB. The latency monitors capture timestamps from the ODUk packets and evaluates the latency from the source packet maker to the monitor point. The latency range is captured for each channel.

The COPI500 transmit (fabric ingress) path provides a Fabric Control Interface to allow COPI500 channel enables to be controlled by an external device. The COPI500 transmit (fabric ingress) path also provides Fabric Path Distribution logic to enable the distribution of ODUk traffic across an arbitrary number of Interlaken channels for load distribution through the fabric. The Fabric Control Interface can be used to select the active Fabric Path Distribution List.

In the COPI500 transmit controller for 3x200G mode the data received from the DCPB for each channel is broadcast to each Interlaken interface that will carry the channel. The COPI500 receive controller filters out the selected channels from each Interlaken interface by dropping the bursts with selected Interlaken channel IDs.

In the transmit controller COPI500PIF performs channel remapping using an Arbitrary Channel Lookup Table to transfer the burst with the required Interlaken channel number. In the receive controller, an Arbitrary Channel Mapping Table is used to reconfigure the channel number of the burst transferred on the DCPB port.

Based on the signaling during the start of packet, the COPI500PIF can optionally prepend PIF packets with a 4-byte header in the transmit direction (from the device to an external device). The optional header carries packet type information (TYPE[7:0]) provided by the DCPB specifying a UPI field from the GFP de-mapper. The UPI value in the TYPE[7:0] field allows the remote packet sink to determine the GFP UPI associated with each de-mapped packet. In the receive (fabric egress) direction, the fourth byte of a packet is optionally extracted and transmitted on the TYPE[7:0] field as a sideband signal to the DCPB; this mode of operation enables the remote packet source to specify the UPI field for packets entering the GFP mapper.

For the COPI500 transmit (fabric ingress) path, COPI500 optionally inserts 4Byte+2Byte user defined per channel values in the CBRI packet headers. In the receive (fabric egress) path, COPI500 extracts the 4Byte+2Byte headers. The 4Byte header is compared with user defined channel values. The 2Byte header may be compared with user defined per channel values or the 2Byte header may be mapped to channel ID values to use instead of the Arbitrary Channel Lookup Table.

The ILKN500 supports in-band flow control on the Interlaken interfaces. The flow control is calendar-based and supported on a per-channel and link (the entire interface) basis. In the receive controller channel level flow control from the DCPB is transmitted over the Interlaken interface and the DCPB absorbs the data received during the flow control response time. The fill level of communal FIFOs in the receive controller are used to generate Link flow control transmitted over the Interlaken interface in the event of prolonged bursts of full bandwidth Interlaken traffic. In the transmit controller the channel flow control received over the Interlaken interfaces for PIF channels is passed on to the DCPB and PIF traffic stops on a burst boundary. The link level flow control received over the Interlaken interfaces for PIF or hybrid PIF and CBRI interfaces halts the traffic on a burst boundary in the transmit controller and backpressures the PIF channels at the DCPB while allowing CBRI data to continue to accumulate in the transmit controller FIFO while it is not full.
